bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 14, 1923

div1.p: Carter responds to Russell's reports and letters that describe Luis Villalobos Corona's illness and post mortem appearance. Carter states that he does not know the cause of death, but believes it is unlikely to be yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 14, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N. C.,
September 14, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p: not noting black vomit between--I would re-

I am returning the paper sent me in your letter of Sept. 11th.
which has just reached me.

Honestly, I don't know of what Senor Corona died. The diagnosis
seems to lie between yellow fever and some intercurrent fever--say mal-
aria--in one with a badly cirrhotic liver.

The appearances which Dr. Herrera notes should almost exclude
yellow fever, yet I notice he does not mention his vomiting while the
report of Dr. Hurtado speaks of constant vomiting. It may be then
that one cannot exclude as non-existent the things not mentioned as oc-
curring in Dr. Herrera's letter. A man dying of yellow fever on the sixth
day, should, however, be very yellow and have bloody gums. Herrera
especially states that the gums were “of uniform color and showed no
modifications along the edges.”

The statement of Dr. Galindo, who, as a sanitary delegate, should
be familiar with yellow fever, implies--though it does not state posi-
tively--that the corpse was not yellow. It is a pity that he had not
done a decent autopsy. We have--on the other hand--the reports (by
Lehmanlaymen that the body “turned completely yellow” and that there was vomit-
ing of dark blood (Dr. Hurtado). The statement of “yellow: green and
and then Bbloody” vomit--I would re-
re-
-2-
gard as rather against the diagnosis of yellowfever and for that of cir-
rhotic liver as, while unchanged blood is sometimes vomited in severe cases of
yellow fever, yet this is extremely rare and I doubt if it occurs --
save possibly in fulminant cases--without being preceeded by the ordinary
black vomit. Indeed, it is not one time in a hundred that the vomit
is recognized as blood by layman. It was not so recognized by physicians until about 1750. This was not a fulminant case, as
he died on the sixth day. Similarly the intestinal evacuations are
rarely noted as bloody--generally the black melaemia.

I am inclined to think that the balance of evidence submitted
is rather against the diagnosis of yellow fever. You know how common
haematmesis and intestinal haemorrhage is in cases of cirrhotic liver.
Whether to lay any stress on the statement that, at the beginning of
the disease, there was no complaint, save a of pain in the abdomen and
legs, I do not know. Histories from patients are very imperfect. As
far as this goes it would be rather against the diagnosis of yellow
fever. It certainly was a very great pity that Dr. Galindo did not
make a complete autopsy.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Enclosures.
P. S. Of course every doubtful case is from a sanitary standpoint to
be treated as yellow fever.
H.R. C.
